revisions.rev:
[[File:Ollanta Humala em BrasÃ­lia.jpg|thumb|President Ollanta Humala in 2011]] The '''foreign policy of [[Ollanta Humala]]''' concerns the policy initiatives made towards other states by the current [[President of Peru]], in difference to past, or future, Peruvian foreign policy as represented by his Foreign Minister [[Rafael Roncagliolo]]. Humala's foreign policy is currently based on relations with other states of the [[Americas]]. {{combi}} |{{Politics of Peru}} {{endcombi}}
==Background== In 2006, Ollanta Humala [[Peruvian general election, 2006|lost]] a run-off to [[Alan GarcÃ­a]]. One reason for his loss was a perception that he too close to Venezuelan President [[Hugo ChÃ¡vez]] and the latter's [[Bolivarian revolution]] based on the principles of [[21st century socialism]] and that he was a part of the "[[pink tide]]" in Latin America. However, five years later he [[Peruvian general election, 2011|beat]] [[Keiko Fujimori]] in a run-off, in part because he distanced himself from Chavez and aligned with the ideas of [[Lula da Silva]] in Brazil, who also experienced similar rapid growth as the [[economy of Peru]].
==2006 presidial candidacy== [[File:Presidente-PiÃ±era-y-presidente-electo-de-PerÃº-Ollanta-Humala.jpg|left|thumb|Humala with Chile's [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era]]{{When|date=August 2011}}]] Questioned by the media, Humala denied any ties to Venezuela's president [[Hugo ChÃ¡vez]], but said he would welcome ChÃ¡vez' support in the 2006 presidential election. On January 3, 2006, [[Evo Morales]] made his first official visit to [[Venezuela]] as President-Elect of [[Bolivia]]. Humala attended the official ceremonies held in the [[Miraflores presidential palace]] in Caracas where both Morales and ChÃ¡vez pledged their support to Humala in his bid for the 2006 presidential race in Peru. In objection to this, Peru recalled its ambassador to Venezuela, [[Carlos Urrutia]], in protest against Venezuela's alleged interference in the election.<ref>[http://www.partidonacionalistaperuano.com/videos/ollanta_chavez2.wmv Humala meeting with ChÃ¡vez 1]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} Video (needs Windows Media Player) {{es icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.partidonacionalistaperuano.com/videos/ollanta_chavez1.wmv Humala meeting with ChÃ¡vez 2]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} Video (needs Windows Media Player) {{es icon}}</ref>{{dead link|date=April 2009}}
In March 2006, Humala also met with President [[NÃ©stor Kirchner]] of [[Argentina]] in Buenos Aires. During the meeting, Humala stated that regional integration took priority over bilateral agreements with the United States and called Kirchner a "brother" in the cause to integrate Latin America. Humala also travelled to meet with Brazilian President [[Lula da Silva]] and officials of his government to discuss regional integration.<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2006/03/02/elmundo/i-03103.htm "Ollanta Humala se reuniÃ³ con Kirchner"] March 2, 2006 ''Clarin'' {{es icon}}</ref><ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20071208224641/http://archivo.larepublica.com.pe/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=104026&fecha_edicion=2006-03-02 "Humala formula propuestas de integraciÃ³n regional a Kirchner"] March 2, 2006 ''La Republica'' {{es icon}}</ref>
On May 8, 2006 Humala met with Bolivian President Evo Morales in [[Copacabana, Bolivia]] on the Bolivian border with Peru. While meeting with Morales Humala stated that he stood in "solidarity with the historical and legitimate demand of the Bolivian Republic" of access to the Pacific Ocean which Bolivia lost after the War of the Pacific when Chile annexed what is now the [[Antofagasta Region]] of Chile. Humala also explicitly stated that he was not opposed to a free trade agreement with the United States but said that any free trade agreement with the United States would have to be negotiated through the [[Andean Community]] (CAN) and signed with approval of all members of CAN. During the meeting Humala emphasised the need to maintain CAN as a bloc to negotiate with the United States and asked Morales to work to help maintain the CAN, referring to the CAN's recent troubles with Venezuela removing itself as a member in protest to the signing of trade agreements with the U.S. by Peru and Colombia.<ref>[http://www.larepublica.com.pe/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=110134&Itemid=565&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09&fecha_edicion=2006-05-09 "Humala solidario con demanda boliviana de salida al mar"]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} May 8, 2006 ''La Republica'' {{es icon}}</ref>
==2011 president-elect== Prior to his official inauguration Humala undertook a tour of American states including Bolivia, Colombia and the United States. (his tour of Venezuela was postponed til 15 July 2011 due to Chavez's health concerns as he underwent surgery in Cuba<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2011/07/14/ollanta-humala-to-visit-chavez-in-caracas.shtml |title=Ollanta Humala to visit ChÃ¡vez in Caracas - Daily News |work=El Universal |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>). Upon resumption of the Venezuela leg of his tour the business community in Peru were concerned that Humala may drift back towards to Chavez's policies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2011/07/15/humala-chavez-and-chavismo/ |title=Humala, ChÃ¡vez and Chavismo | beyondbrics | News and views on emerging markets from the Financial Times â FT.com |publisher=Blogs.ft.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}</ref>
===Pan-Americas tour=== His first visit as president-elect was to Brazil. Following a meeting with Brazilian President Dilma Roussef he said though the situation in Peru and Brazil is different, both countries' plan was similar along the lines of economic growth and prudent macroeconomic management. He added that: "We are pleased with this meeting. Brazil is an important strategic partner for Peru. Brazil is a successful model of economic growth." He then left for Paraguay where he met President [[Fernando Lugo]], following which he planned to visit Urugya, Argentina and Chile.<ref>http://www.latindailyfinancialnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9799%3Abrazil-and-peru&catid=217%3Apolitics&Itemid=701&lang=en</ref>
Following a meeting in 2006 with Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]] in [[Copacabana, Bolivia|Copacabana]] on the Bolivian border with Peru, in which Humala stated that he stood in "solidarity with the historical and legitimate demand of the Bolivian Republic,"{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} after his electoral victory in 2011 he went back to Bolivia and made calls for the resurrection of the [[PeruâBolivian Confederation]].<ref name="amrica"/> Bolivian Communications Minister [[Ivan Canelas]] announced that he would meet Morales and discuss Bolivia's maritime [[Bolivia-Chile relations|claim]] against Chile (for which Peru expressed tacit support). Humala also added that he had "a widely shared vision of integration [with Morales]. For me, it's an important meeting, [Bolivia] is an [[Aymara]] and sister nation." (However Peru's large indigenous population is mostly [[Quechua people|Quechua]])<ref name="peru-bol"/>
Humala also visited Colombia where he met one of the only two conservative president's left in South America, [[Juan Manuel Santos]]. The two leaders of talked integration projects between Colombia and Peru.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ntn24news.com/videos/perus-humala-talks-about-his-visit-colombia |title=Peru's Humala talks about his visit to Colombia |publisher=NTN24 NEWS |date=2011-06-29 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref>
During a visit to Washington, D.C. Humala also met [[Organization of American States]]' Secretary-General [[Jose Miguel Insulza]] in which he said Peru intends to work towards greater [[Latin American integration|regional integration]].<ref name="amrica">{{cite web|url= http://www.livinginperu.com/news/15491 |title= Ollanta Humala reaffirms his commitment to Peruvian-Bolivian solidarity |publisher=Living in Peru |date= |accessdate=2011-07-16}}{{dead link|date=July 2011}}</ref> During the same tour he also met with US [[Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] on Washington, D.C. During the meeting US President [[Barack Obama]] made a surprise appearance to meet Humala, a visit that was appreciated by the latter. Obama spoke of the importance of "sound market-based economic policies with efforts to increase economic and social inclusion."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=ldP68UyW5+Q= |title= Humala, Obama agree Peru, US should be 'equal partners' |publisher=ANDINA |date=2011-07-07 |accessdate=2011-07-30}}</ref> Peruvian ambassador Luis Valdivieso said that the visit was an "extraordinary step" in starting relations at the highest level between the Humala government and the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/Noticia.aspx?Id=mo3cU63B5yc= |title=Humala's visit to US was an extraordinary step, the ambassador says |publisher=ANDINA |date=2011-07-16 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref>
During his postponed trip to Venezuela, Humala was personally welcomes by Chavez at [[Miraflores Palace]]. He reiterated calls for regional integreation saying "As 200 years ago, when we fought colonialism, today we have common enemies like poverty, inequalities, drug trafficking and so many threats against our countries. I have come as a friend and a brother; and this brotherhood leads us to a similar future." He also wished Chavez a recovery from his cancer treatment: "We are giving you support, please count on our forces and the prayers of the Peruvian people, who want your recovery because you have a mission to accomplish." Humala also paid a visit to [[SimÃ³n BolÃ­var]]'s birthplace house and met with officials at the headquarters of the ''Corporacion Andina de Fomento''.
He was then due to travel to Mexico on 18 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.escambray.cu/Eng/world/humala110715943 |title=Ollanta Humala Welcomed by Chavez in Venezuela â Escambray |publisher=Escambray.cu |date= |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> In meeting President [[Felipe CalderÃ³n]] at [[Los Pinos|Palace Los Pinos]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntn24news.com/videos/ollanta-humala-visits-mexico |title=Ollanta Humala visits Mexico |publisher=NTN24 NEWS |date=2011-07-18 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> he said that "With Mexico, after July 28, we are going to improve relations that already are excellent. We want to improve commercial exchange even more so" and "strengthen relations in the area of education."<ref>{{cite web|author=July 19, 2011 |url=http://www.peruviantimes.com/19/humala-visits-mexico-and-cuba-prior-to-inauguration/13096/ |title=Humala visits Mexico and Cuba prior to inauguration |publisher=Peruvian Times |date=2011-07-19 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> They also discussed the general strengthening of [[Mexico-Peru relations]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/news/15518 |title=News Â» President-elect Humala arrives in Mexico to meet with Calderon |publisher=Living in Peru |date=2011-07-18 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> After Mexico he visited Cuba, a move that ''[[Granma]]'' quoted Humala as saying that he had come to visit a "sister" country and to share an "open agenda" with [[President of Cuba|President]] [[Raul Castro]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2011/07/19/peruvian-president-elect-visits-cuba/ |title=Peruvian President-Elect Visits Cuba Â« VOA Breaking News |publisher=Blogs.voanews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> He also met leftist political icon and Cuban commander-in-chief [[Fidel Castro]]. The two leaders talked of the "happy atmosphere" as well as the "complicated situation in Latin America." His talks with Raul Castro focused on [[Cuba-Peru relations]] and the "need" to enhance education via Cuba's "[[Yes I Can]]" educational programme. In doing so he cited Cuba's success in contributing to the eradication of illiteracy in countries such as Venezuela, Nicaragua, Bolivia and Ecuador.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cubanews.ain.cu/2011/0720ollanta-humala.htm |title=Ollanta Humala Returns to Peru after Meeting with Fidel and Raul |publisher=Cubanews.ain.cu |date=1972-07-08 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref>
===Inauguration=== His [[Peruvian general election, 2011#Inauguration|inauguration]] on 28 July was due to be attended by regional leaders. Foreign dignitaries such as Colombia's Juan Manuel Santos were scheduled to attend the event,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=J+RtcQN7wqE= |title=Colombian president to attend CAN Summit, Humala's inauguration | ANDINA - Peru News Agency |publisher=ANDINA |date=2011-07-20 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> along with Brazil's [[Dilma Rousseff]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=F0dgngkR67k= |title=Brazilian president to attend Humala's inauguration | ANDINA - Peru News Agency |publisher=ANDINA |date= |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> Uruguay's [[JosÃ© Mujica]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/Noticia.aspx?Id=G/HcvHbIIAs= |title=Uruguayan president to attend Humala's inauguration | ANDINA - Peru News Agency |publisher=ANDINA |date= |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> Panama's [[Ricardo Martinelli]],<ref name="statement">{{cite web|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/news-235-Heads-of-state-arrive-to-Peru-for-Humala-inauguration/ |title=Heads Of State Arrive To Peru For Humala Inauguration |publisher=Livinginperu.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-30}}</ref> (and his wife First Lady [[Marta Linares de Martinelli]]),<ref>{{cite web|author=Don Winner |url=http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20110727150743687 |title=Martinelli Traveling To Peru To Attend Ollanta Humala's Inauguration |publisher=Panama Guide |date= |accessdate=2011-07-30}}</ref> Argentina's [[Cristina FernÃ¡ndez de Kirchner]], Chile's [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era]], Ecuador's [[Rafael Correa]],<ref name="voaguests"/> Bolvia's Evo Morales, Guatemala's [[Ãlvaro Colom]], Hondurasâ [[Porfirio Lobo]],<ref>http://coa.counciloftheamericas.org/articles/3526/Ollanta_Humala_Takes_Presidential_Helm_in_Peru/</ref> South Africa's [[Jacob Zuma]]<ref>http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/zuma-inauguration-guest-list-1.441552</ref> and Georgia's [[Mikheil Saakashvili]].<ref>http://pik.tv/en/news/story/15682-president-saakashvili-attends-inauguration-in-peru</ref> They would also be joined by Cuban First Vice President [[Jose Ramon Machado Ventura]] and his delegation,<ref>[http://www.plenglish.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=310119&Itemid=1 Prensa Latina News Agency - Cuban Vice President to Attend Ollanta Humala Inauguration]. Plenglish.com (1 January 1970). Retrieved on 28 July 2011.</ref> Spain's [[crown prince]] [[Felipe, Prince of Asturias]],<ref name="perutimes">http://www.peruviantimes.com/29/ollanta-humala-inaugurated-as-perus-president/13223/</ref> Secretary-general of the [[Organization of American States]] [[Jose Miguel Insulza]], the U.S. ambassador,<ref name="voaguests">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2011/07/28/peru-swears-in-humala-as-president/ |title=Peru Swears In Humala as President Â« VOA Breaking News |publisher=Blogs.voanews.com |date=2009-08-20 |accessdate=2011-07-29}}</ref> the brother of South Korean President [[Lee Myung-bak]], [[Lee Sang-deuk]] of the incumbent [[Grand National Party]]<ref>[http://www.livinginperu.com/news/15535 News Â» South Korean president's envoy to attend Humala inauguration]. Living in Peru (19 July 2011). Retrieved on 28 July 2011.</ref> and Chinese President [[Hu Jintao]]'s special envoy Minister of Agriculture [[Han Changfu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/Noticia.aspx?id=6sWUxpLivBE= |title=Chinese envoy to attend Humala's inauguration | ANDINA - Peru News Agency |publisher=ANDINA |date=2011-07-22 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref>
==Relations with individual states== ===Chile=== {{see|Chile-Peru relations}} The new Foreign Minister [[Rafael Roncagliolo]] met his Chilean counterpart [[Alfredo Moreno Charme]] prior to taking office. Following the meeting he said that Charme was "a concerned person, who has an attitude of dialogue and does not encourage unnecessary antagonism" and added that in regards to the [[ChileanâPeruvian maritime dispute]] "by going to [[the Hague]], what we are looking for is peaceful understanding, avoid lawsuits and verbal arguments. Peru has taken the position of a modern civilized nation to go to court. Resolve conflicts by means of right reason, not force." However he also commented on Chilean military spending vis-a-vis its neighbours: "When a country develops a quite disproportionate military capacity compared to their neighbours, others are right to worry. That is the situation we face. Yes, we should worry. Chile's military spending is disproportionate to the neighbours. That is why Peru, in [[UNASUR]] is promoting transparency and a reduction of military spending. There are more important things you must invest in Latin America. All countries must have a credible military defense, and Peru has not maintained one like this."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peruthisweek.com/news-219-Perus-next-foreign-minister-on-relations-with-Chile/ |title=Peru's Next Foreign Minister On Relations With Chile |publisher=Peruthisweek.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-30}}</ref>
Prior to Humala's visit to Bolivia in his pre-inauguration pan-Americas tour, Peru agreed to cede territory claimed by Bolivia against Chile so as to facilitate resolution of the maritime claim. The 1929 [[Peace and Friendship treaty]], which formalised relations between the three states following the [[War of the Pacific]], requires Peru's "prior agreement" to pursue further negotiations for Chile to cede former Peruvian territory to a third party and settle the conflict.<ref name="peru-bol">{{cite web|url=http://www.boliviaweekly.com/humala-visits-burnt-palace-morales-expected-to-discuss-pacific-access/2168/ |title=Humala Visits Burnt Palace; Morales Expected to Discuss Pacific Access |publisher=Bolivia Weekly |date= |accessdate=2011-07-30}}</ref>
